characters: VIEWED FROM FAR BACK IN THE CHURCH
AT THE BACK OF THE CAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white cross on the church steeple stands against blue The church bell rings, resonating. Mass has let out.  Small church, small congregation.  The road in front is lined with pick-up trucks and parishione foot heading to outlying farms and homes.  An old two-sto house sits across the road.  Lone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight comes through the soot on the windows, more brow bright.  SOMERSET, 45, in a suit and tie, stands in this second-story room.  He looks around, at the ceiling, at t wooden floor, at the peeling wallpaper on the walls. Somerset walks to one wall where the current wallpaper is away to reveal flowery wallpaper underneath.  He runs his across one of the pale red roses that decorates the older He pushes the grime away, brings the rose out more clearl He pulls at the edge of the paper, carefully ripping off roughly squared section with the rose at its center. He studies it in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birds sing.  Somerset stands, pondering the forested land

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset does not respond. The MAN, in an ill-fitting rea estate jacket, is seated on the hood of a dirty Ford Thunderbird.  He holds a check and a booklet of receipts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is something the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... no.  There's nothing wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset still seems distant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (writes receipt) Not that it's any of my business... but, are you figuring on moving out here eventually?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just never seen a man mortgaging an empty house before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything here still seems... seems so strange to me.  All this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I'd say this place is about as normal as places get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man walks over to hand over a receipt.  Somerset acce receipt, folds it.  Somerset smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is exactly what I mean.  Strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset looks back at the house.  The man does not under

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset is in a window seat, smoking a cigarette, lookin the speeding train.  He is near the back of the car, away the few other passengers. Outside, farms, small homes and lawns pass.  The entire p is dappled by the rays of the soon setting sun. The light flickers across Somerset's placid face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train is nearly full.  Somerset has his suitcase on t aisle seat beside him.  He has a hardcover book unopened lap.  He still stares out the window, but his disposition soured.  The train is passing an ugly, swampy field. A car's burnt-out skeleton sits rusting in the bracken. further on, two dogs are fighting, circling, attacking, t coats matted with blood. Somerset turns his head to watch the dogs. Away in the field, another dog sprints to join the fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passing urban streets below.  Slums.  Smashed cars.  Peop stand on the corners, under the bleak glow of street lamp Somerset's suitcase is by the window.  Somerset is now in aisle seat, reading his book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtains closed.  The SOUNDS of the CITY are here as they be everywhere in this story.  A CAR ALARM SHRIEKS.  Somer life is packed in many moving boxes, except for clothing closet and hundreds of books on shelves. Somerset, dressed only in his underwear, lays back on the He reaches to the nightstand, to a wooden, pyramidical metronome. He frees the metronome's weighted swingarm so it moves ba forth.  Swings to the left... TICK, swings to the right.. Tick, tick, tick, measured and steady. Somerset situates on the bed, closes his eyes.  The metro ticking competes with the sound of the car alarm.  Somers face tightens as he concentrates on the metronome. His eyes close tighter. Tick, tick, tick... the swingarm moves evenly.  Somerset' breathing deepens.  The car ALARM seems QUIETER. Tick, tick, tick.  Somerset continues his concentration. The METRONOME is the ONLY SOUND.  Somerset's face relaxes slightly as he begins to fall asleep.  Tick, tick, tick..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID MILLS, 31, exits with a bagged 40oz bottle of beer. a lean, attractive man, constantly coiled, eyes always smoldering.  FOLLOW as he walks quickly past iron-gated storefronts.  He crosses the street under elevated subway tracks.  A train roars overhead. Mills watches it as he walks on. Blue sparks spit off the third rail and illuminate Mills, throwing his shadow long down the deserted street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This rotting neighborhood lives in the shadow of a single skyscraper.  Mills walks, looks at the broken refrigerato pieces of junk in the gutter. Ahead in the street, TWO YOUNG THUGS struggle with a crow break into the trunk of a parked car. Mills draws near.  One thug looks up, doesn't think Mills be a problem, continues prying.  Mills stops, calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that your car, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck do you care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills pauses, switches his beer bottle to his other hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that car belong to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thugs look at each other, gauging.  They face Mills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's my car, alright?  Fuck off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're telling me that's your car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second thug starts the long way round the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, for some strange reason, I don't believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills gives a "isn't that silly" laugh, shifts his gaze - Sees the first thug slide the crowbar so it's held as a w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (steps forward) You can fucking suck my...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills swiftly finishes that sentence by smashing his bott against the first thug's head.  The thug falls, swings bl The second thug moves from the side, brings out a knife. Mills averts, swings, pounds the side of his fist into th second thug's face -- CRACK.  Broken nose. The second thug stumbles back, drops the knife, his nose squirting blood. Mills turns, enraged, breathing hard. The first thug is screaming, trying to stand.  Mills take step, punts the first thug's head.  The crowbar clatters Mills is in the process of kicking a man when he's down, the second thug grabs him from behind, pulls him backward Mills clutches at the thug's arm, trying to avoid a choke They both struggle spastically.  The thug's winning. Gurgling, gasping for air, Mills shifts his weight, drops knee and spins the thug, slamming him against the car. Mills breaks loose, grabs a handful of the second thug's and holds the man's head against the car's side window. free hand pounds the thug's face: once, twice -- third ti the charm as the window shatters.  The thug goes out cold Mills backs off, still incensed.  He rubs his throat, loo the two prone men.  Slowly, he regains some composure. He takes a keychain from his pocket.  He unlocks the door car, loads one of the thugs into the back seat.  He walks collect the other thug off the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset picks items off a moving box:  keys, wallet, hom badge.  Finally, he opens the hardcover book from the tra From the pages, he takes the pale, wallpaper rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wall is stained by a starburst of blood.  Somerset stan melancholy, looking at a body on the floor under a sheet sawed-off shotgun.  The apartment is gloomy.  DETECTIVE T 52, looks through a notepad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neighbors heard them screaming at each other.  It was nothing new or unusual. But, then they heard the gun go off. Boom, boom... both barrels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did his wife confess?  Did she actually speak the words?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the patrolman got here she was trying to put his head back together. She was crying too hard to say anything. (shuts notebook) Crime of passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Look at all the passion splattered up on the wall here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor shifts his weight, impatient, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a done deal.  All but the paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset looks at a coloring-book open on the coffee tabl There are crayons beside it.  Somerset picks the book up. He flips through: crudely colored pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did their son see it happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of question is that?  Huh? (pointing) He's dead.  His wife killed him.  There it is.  That's all.  Anything else has nothing to do with nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset replaces the book, digs up a cigarette from his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and your fucking questions, Somerset.  I'm glad I'm getting rid of you today.  You know that, you fuck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Mills enters, dressed in a suit.  He looks a bit lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... Lieutenant Somerset?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset lights his cigarette, looks to Mills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm David Mills... your new partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A body-bag is carried through the crowd around the teneme doors.  Somerset follows.  Mills follows Somerset.  They towards the end of the filthy block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little thrown.  I just finished orientation at central, and they dumped me off down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you brought in two small-timers last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Two real idiots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since we are just starting out, I thought we could go to a bar.  Sit and talk for awhile.  That way we can...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but I'd rather start sniffing for a case, if it's all the same to you. Seeing how we only have a week for this whole transition thing. (waits) I want to get into the shit a.s.a.p., know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset walks, no reply.  Mills searches to get a read o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant to ask you something... when we spoke on the phone.  I can't help wondering... (pause) Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wary) I... I don't follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this effort you've gone through, to be transferred from Philadelphia to here.  It's the first question that pops into my head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills formulates his response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here for the same reasons as you, I guess.  Or... at least the same reasons you used to have for being here... (cutting) ...before you decided to give up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset stops and faces Mills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you know me?  You just met me two minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I don't understand the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very simple.  You've come from the "City of Brotherly Love" to the "City of Brotherly Hate," detective.  I've never seen it done that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Maybe I thought I could do more good here than there. (pause) You know, it'd be great by me if we didn't start right out kicking each other in the balls.  But, you're calling the shots, lieutenant, so however you want it to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you how I want this to go. I want you to look, and I want you to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't standing around Philly guarding the fucking Liberty Bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, you've never worked homicide in this city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I realize that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, please do me the favor of remembering it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills just stares back at Somerset.  Somerset walks.  Mil rolls his eyes, looks to heaven like, "what'd I do to des this?"  He follows Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset lies asleep on the bed.  It is still dark outsid Relatively quiet.  The PHONE beside the inactive metronom HARSHLY.  Somerset awakens suddenly, rankled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is barely becoming light outside.  Mills can't sleep. Alone in a double bed.  He sits up, frustrated.  Sits on edge of the bed and looks around.  The room is a shambles filled with moving boxes. The light coming through the window glows upon a football on one box.  Large and noble, a golden player stands in f motion at the trophy's pinnacle. Mills looks at the trophy and a fond smile forms on his f The CLINKING of DISHES and SILVERWARE is HEARD from anoth room.  Mills looks at the closed bedroom door, troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across a living room full of boxes, TRACY MILLS, 30, a be woman, stands in her bathrobe.  She's upset about somethi takes dishes out of boxes, puts them on the kitchenette c She pulls a mug from a clump of newspaper and pours some from a pot on the stove.  Blowing on the steaming tea, sh back on the counter, looks over at the closed bedroom doo The tea is too hot to sip, and as Tracy is placing the mu the counter behind her the PHONE RINGS.  Startled, she re the mug too close to the edge.  It falls -- Crashes to the floor, shatters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark hall.  Somerset and Mills stand with OFFICER DAVIS beefy, uniformed cop.  Light from a camera's flash spills from the nearby kitchen.  Davis hands Somerset two flashl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At what time did you confirm the death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said, we didn't touch anything, but we were on scene at like o-five- hundred, so he's had his face in a plate of spaghetti for about half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, wait.  You didn't check him? You didn't check vital signs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, he's gone.  Unless he's breathing spaghetti sauce now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  The point is, when you're first man in, you check vital signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy's sitting in a pile of his own shit and piss.  If he ain't dead he would have stood up by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting angry) Listen, Godzilla...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset steps in, heads Mills off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Officer Davis.  We'll see you again after we've had a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davis leaves, eyeing Mills.  Mills watches him.  Somerset Mills a flashlight, takes out surgical gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder what exactly was the point of the conversation you were about to get into?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, I wonder how many times Officer Davis there has found a supposedly dead man who didn't really die until Davis was back in the patrol car calling the morgue and eating a powdered donut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset snaps one glove over his hand and checks the fit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop it.  We have more important concerns just now, don't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine... for now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The POLICE PHOTOGRAPHER packs up, hoists his camera and equipment bag.  Somerset and Mills enter.  Mills puts on pair of rubber gloves.  The grubby kitchen is small; bare for four people to move around in.  The photographer exit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bon appetit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only light is a murky green illumination from the cei The light bathes an OBESE MAN who is slumped forward in a kitchen chair, face-down-dead in a plate of spaghetti. The sizable kitchen table's green tablecloth is covered w soiled paper plates.  The plates hold bits of half-eaten sandwiches, potatoes, donuts and other junk-food remnants Mills and Somerset turn on their flashlights.  Mills poin at the green bulb above.  Aluminum foil has been wrapped the bulb to focus the light on the corpse. Somerset sweeps the room with his flashlight.  He goes to body and kneels beside it.  There's a rope tied around th man's wide gut.  Mills comes to stand beside Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that makes it homicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset crouches lower, uses a pen to lift one of the de man's pants cuffs.  Rope is tied around the purplish ankl Mills examines the knots behind the chair's back.  Shines flashlight on the man's belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, he could have tied himself in. To make it look like murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset isn't listening, focused on the corpse.  He stud man's head and neck without touching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see any blood or bruises yet. No wounds.  You see anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset stands, points his flashlight: the obese man's s hands are clutching utensils.  A knife in the left hand, sticking straight up in the right with a hunk of meat han skewered.  Cockroaches swarm. Mills turns to the sink and stove.  Each burner of the st a used pot or pan on it.  There's food slopped everywhere

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw a guy once... committed suicide, but he wanted to make sure his family could collect insurance money, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset walks to the room's only window.  The window has painted over with black paint.  he touches the window wit pinkie finger.  The paint is still wet. Mills goes to a trash can by the refrigerator.  The trash full to the brim with empty food containers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, this guy took this big knife... and he held it behind him, put the tip of it in his back, and he ran backwards into the wall.  Cause, he thought it was going to look like someone stabbed him in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills opens the refrigerator.  It's nearly empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except, he poked a big fucking hole in the dry wall when he did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could... spare me the anecdotes for now.  Leave the refrigerator open for the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Oh, forgive me.  I thought we had this male-bonding thing going.  My mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset looks at the floor, deep in thought.  His flashl beam follows a trail of dripped sauces, soups and bits of running from the stove to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you smell?  Other than him, and all the food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sniffs) I don't know... there's something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset goes close to the table, then leans to peer unde

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bucket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset points the flashlight and Mills crouches, pulls tablecloth on his side of the table.  Two large dead rats the floor beside a metal bucket. Mills grimaces, slides under the table, careful to avoid rats.  He looks in the bucket.  He leans back, baffled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's vomit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Somerset under the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bucket of vomit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any blood in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't tell by looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset stands, perplexed, stares at the dead man.  Ther knock at the door.  The detectives look to DOCTOR THOMAS O'NEILL, 52, the medical examiner.  O'Neill is a frumpy m seems a bit gone, looking at the green bulb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mood lighting.  Very sixties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops his bag on the floor, sorts through the contents

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Somerset) You think he was poisoned?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills goes to the trash can, pokes the garbage with a pen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, those rats there somehow ate the poison off the floor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guessing this early is useless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You girls have got the forensics guys out there chompin' at the bit.  Don't know if we'll all fit in here though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills continues searching the garbage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's room.  Light's the problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, three is certainly a crowd in here.  And, with four, someone's bound to be stepping on evidence. (pause) Detective Mills, go help the officers question the neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not pleased) Thanks, but no thanks.  I'll stay on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset watches O'Neill at the corpse.  O'Neill points a flashlight with his mouth, his hands free for the examina

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Send one forensic in on your way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills is pissed.  He lifts his flashlight to shine it on side of Somerset's face. A moment passes.  Somerset looks at Mills, light shining directly in Somerset's eyes.  A longer moment.  Mills swi the light off.  He leaves. O'Neill unceremoniously places both hands on the dead man head, lifts the swollen visage from the spaghetti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THWACK, THWACK... THWACK.  Mills punches the heavy bag wi hard, quick punches.  Sweat drips off his face.  He's in out clothing, a bundle of nerves wearing boxing gloves. The walls are covered in mirrors.  Other cops watch Mills they pass, checking out the new kid.  Mills keeps punchin skillfully. He stops when he sees Somerset reflected in one of the mi Somerset walks over, carrying a pizza box with paper pile top.  He sits on a near bench, takes out a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pizza and paperwork, Detective Mills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to chat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills opens a door and enters with Somerset behind.  They alone.  Chairs face an old, limp-roped boxing ring.  Prac pads hang from pegs on a wall.  Mills clasps a pair in hi gloves, offers them to Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just hold them up.  I do all the work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset takes the pads reluctantly, puts them on.  He st the un-lit cigarette hanging from his mouth.  Mills climb the ring.  He holds the ropes open for Somerset, waits. Somerset doesn't want to do this, but he climbs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've seen my files... seen the things I've done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Impressive work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills motions to Somerset and Somerset holds up the pract pads.  Mills starts working them, lightly, warming up. THWACK... THWACK...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what's your problem?  I've done my time on door-to-doors, and walking a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it.  That doesn't mean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did all that shit a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THWACK... THWACK... Somerset's very stiff, uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made a decision, because I have to worry about the integrity of the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I'm on scene, I'm not going to worry whether you think you're getting enough time on the playing field.  I'm there to do the work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills punches a little more aggressively.  Somerset's bac flinching, keeping the pads high.  THWACK... THWACK... TH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The badge in my pocket says "detective," just like yours.  I've been Homicide for four and a half years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've worked Homicide for four years, or for five years... Don't count the half-years, unless you want to sound like a rookie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills unloads a mighty wallop and one practice pad recoil Somerset's face, knocks Somerset on his ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oops.  My hand slipped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills walks, climbs out of the ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fucked me over today, and you know it.  You know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset looks at the broken cigarette in his mouth.  He contains his anger.  He seems to realize Mills has a poin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just don't jerk me off.  That's all I ask.  It's not much.  Don't jerk me off. (pause) Please, do me the favor of remembering that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills exits.  Somerset spits out the broken cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy looks out a window from behind steel bars. Below her, young children play in a playground.  They're hop-scotch, throwing balls, chasing each other.  The swin are broken.  The handball wall is graffitied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mrs. Mills.  We don't have anything right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy looks away from the window to the haggard WOMAN.  T school's office is ill-equipped, busy, disorganized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll try to give you a call if we need substitutes next month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy looks back at the playground: on the other side of chain-link fence, a butcher in a bloody apron walks down ramp of a freezer truck.  he carries a big, whole, slaugh pig on his shoulder. The pig's head flops as the butcher walks.  Some children their games and run to watch the man and the pig corpse p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train clatters through a tunnel, packed full, WHEELS SCREECHING.  The lights go on and off.  Passengers read tabloids, stare at their feet, study advertisements on th walls; anything to avoid making eye-contact with others. All races, creeds and colors; all ugly, forlorn human bei Tracy stands fatigued, holding a handrail. A bag-lady, crusted with dirt, reeking, pushes her way th the crowd.  A man presses against Tracy in an attempt to bag-lady pass.  Tracy switches hands on the rail, turns s to make room.  She looks down. dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A narrow room.  SPEED METAL is even LOUDER.  This is a pr art party.  The people are lizard-like, pale.  Men and wo priding themselves on their gauntness. Somerset passes canvases on the walls.  Pointlessly abstr paintings.  Splatters, smears and blobs of color. Party-people stand in front of these "works," engrossed. Somerset slides past, not interested in the art, jamming tissue further in his ears.  He spots his objective. WILLIAM McCRACKEN, 42, stands inside a circle of admirers dressed like a pauper, his baggy clothing stained with ma colors of paint.  He wears dark sunglasses, bored by the bleached-blonde girl whispering in his ear. Somerset worms his way to stand in front of William.  The goers turn their attention to this intrusion. William looks up, pushes the girl away.  He takes off his sunglasses.  His eyes are badly bloodshot and listless. He looks Somerset over... and then grins, glad to see him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills stands brooding over a photocopy of the picture of woman with her eyes circled in blood.  He looks overworke drinks coffee.  His desk is swamped with files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have voiced the same concerns to our law enforcement officials, and they assure me he is of the highest caliber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills looks to a t.v. on a table, picks up a remote, incr the volume.  On the screen, MARTIN TALBOT, 47, source of voice, stands before reporters.  He's a powerful presence a gold tooth in the front of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from t.v.) As District Attorney, don't you feel some responsibility?  Detective David Mills lacks the experience...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from t.v.) I've always said... I've always said, don't send a boy to do a man's job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills is hanging on every word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, David Mills has a sterling record with the Philadelphia force.  I stand behind him one hundred percent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved) You tell 'em boss.  Detective David Mills is a wonderful human being...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However... however... let me say this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills looks back at the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Detective Mills, at any point in this investigation... if he is not pulling his weight, I will be the first in line to pull his plug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills points the remote, turns the t.v. off as reporters Talbot.  Mills stares at the blank screen, dispirited. Across the room, Tracy stands in the doorway.  Mills does see her.  He looks at the photocopy and sits at his desk. Tracy watches him, great concern in her sad eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset walks through this vast artist's studio, a conve warehouse space filled with canvases.  It's clear the wor the underground art gallery were William's.  William clim ladder to a loft storage space.  He moves cautiously, lik not quite up to the task.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always figured that's the only reason you and I used to be friends.  Because I was a friend of hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William yanks a painting wrapped in dusty paper, climbs d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking of which...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William hands the painting to Somerset, walks to a direct chair facing a paint-splashed canvas on an easel.  He is up man, bound in an apathy-induced haze.  He sits, picks squeeze bottle of orange paint from a table of supplies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I painted that about five years ago.  I always told myself I'd give it to you next time I saw you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset starts unwrapping the painting. William "paints," using the squeeze bottles and by flicki saturated brushes so that the paint flies against the can Most times, he's not even looking at the canvas or colors using.  He looks over his shoulder at Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things are different these days, pal. You wouldn't believe it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset looks at the unwrapped painting and is hit by a of memories.  Horribly sad memories.  It's a portrait in a pretty, red-headed woman. William shoots red paint with one hand, concentrates on lighting a filterless cigarette with the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People buy my paintings now... they drive down in their BMWs and Rolls Royces.  It's the new money generation. I guess they think they're touching the avant-garde...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William looks at his creation, then calmly kicks the ease

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's another thousand dollar William McCracken expression of anarchy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William gets up, walks across the wet canvas, leaving footprints.  He looks down at what he's done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make that two thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs.  Somerset holds up the delicately rendered por

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is she?  Have you seen her recently?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh... oh.  No.  She moved out of the city.  Last winter.  She married some businessman, or something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset fights the anguish this causes, puts the paintin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for her. (pause) I'm leaving soon myself.  I'm finally getting out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  What happened to the idealistic super-cop I used to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He became a realist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William grunts, flicks his cigarette away, takes out a ba pills.  He palms a few, notices the judgment in Somerset'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William turns his back to Somerset, pops the pills.  Out sight, out of mind.  Somerset is disappointed, disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Not that I don't appreciate your recent artistic endeavors... but, what happened to the painter I used to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William smiles like a dolt, laughs a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Color photos of the first and second murder sit on a draw table.  The top photos are like establishing shots, each in the entire display the murderer created. William examines with Somerset looking over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man... can I buy these from you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not for sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset lays out photos of the notes, triangle and circl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?  What's the murderer trying to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William narrows his eyes.  Does not know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What picture is he painting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (figuring) Wait a minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William has an idea.  He ambles over to a row of cabinets oversized art books are stacked.  He hunts through a pile shoves some books aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I've seen things like that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William keeps digging, finds one book, finds another.  He one as he walks back to the drawing table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's church stuff.  Christianity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William lays a book down, finds a page.  He opens it to Somerset.  There is a circle to the side of the text.  It GLUTTONY under the circle. Somerset creases his brow, turns the page.  William opens another book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When it first started... Christian artwork was all from Bible stories.  It was like... nobody had any imagination. It was all... standardized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William pages through and we catch glimpses of the bizarr worlds of Hieronymus Bosch.  Horrifying religious visions

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, later, everyone started painting to tell their own stories... to teach lessons.  Guys like Bosch, Bregel the elder... Van Eycks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William shoves the open book to Somerset.  Somerset looks Seven paintings in a circular pattern showing characters in to sins.  Wicked, grotesque people. Somerset turns the book to examine each painting right si

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The seven deadly sins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what these murders remind me of. Paintings like these. (points) Gluttony... greed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Envy, wrath, pride, lust and sloth. Seven deadly sins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen, brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William goes to continue pulling other books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can find more examples.  There's lots of paintings like those... painted over hundreds of years. (moves books) And you're right... that murderer is an artist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset is chilled by all this, immersed in the Bosch bo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, it's two down... five to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bright, tawdry intersection.  Neon swirls and circuit-b porno theatres provide the flash.  Cars, taxies, and bark urging sexual indulgence from doorways provide the noise. The streets and sidewalks are crowded with lonely humans, men, looking around, sizing up promises made on porno pla FUN WITH NUDES, BIG BOOBS, NAKED DESIRE, etc.  The usual contingent of abnormal cretins wanders in the crowd, look someone to hurt. MOVE through the crowds.  Meet JOHN, a balding, middle-ag wearing thick glasses.  There is not a single thing stran unusual about his appearance.  FOLLOW him as he walks.  H nervous, looking at the porno palaces. His sweaty hand clutches a Bible tight against his chest. doesn't feel comfortable being here. John walks to a corner, waits for the light so he may cro grotesque STREET PREACHER approaches waving his own Bible People walk away from him, so he confronts John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...are you, Sir?  Is Jesus Christ your Lord and Master?  Do you believe in Him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John tries to ignore, traffic blocking his escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading) Don't ignore me.  Listen to what I have to say.  Christ can be your savior!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet anger) Leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about God, sir.  I can help you let Him into your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally the light changes.  John turns and spits in the preacher's face.  The preacher recoils as John crosses qu John hurries between cars in the crosswalk.  The preacher from the corner, his voice drowned out in traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People pass on the sidewalk.  John is amongst them, but h stops, looking up at something offscreen. He's looking at a bright red storefront adorned with red THE HOT HOUSE.  Massage parlor.  The Hot House's BARKER n John's interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting isn't it, friend?  You like that, you like girls, then come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John doesn't hear the barker.  Steps up to study fading p of naked women massaging happy men.  Nudity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see a lot more inside.  You'll see a lot more than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John's just looking, his face bathed in bright red light, neon reflected in his thick glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset, holding more than an armful of art books and no pounds on the apartment door.  Tracy opens it with the ch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a second to drink Somerset in.  Somerset is sur having expected Mills.  Tracy is so exquisite that he fal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... I was looking for Mills.  David, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not here right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset tries not to drop any books while he digs up his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mills, my name is Somerset.  If I could leave these books for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (undoes chain) Please, come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy leads Somerset into the disarray of the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David went for a walk.  To clear his head.  Oh, you can put those here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy motions and Somerset puts the books on Mills' desk. He starts looking through one book, checking paperclipped

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you tell him... tell him this is his reading assignment.  It's urgent. I've marked the most important pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like some coffee, or a drink. David should be back any minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do have to get going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset sees a medal encased in glass on the desk amongs and pencils.  He picks it up: it's a medal for valor from Philadelphia Police Department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least I got to meet you.  David has told me a lot about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  Good things, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.  He said you were very smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's a bit intimidated by you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset thinks about this, finds it hard to believe.  He through his pocket, pulls out a notepad and some paper sc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to leave him a list of specifics.  It all relates to the case he's on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lays the various scraps and receipts aside on the desk to start writing on the notepad.  Tracy goes to the kitch to get a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two aren't working together anymore. Isn't that so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be perfectly honest, Mrs. Mills...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy.  David and I weren't exactly what you could call fast friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy brings the chair over by the desk and sits.  Somers looks up from his writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt your husband shares that opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy nods, leaning forward, semi-conspiratorially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Somerset, David is very... determined.  I'm sure you've seen, it's not likely he'll ever be compared to Gandhi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a good cop.  He just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees policework as a crusade.  That's what he wants it to be, and, that might sound naive, but he's made a conscious choice to be naive. (pause) Believe me, his heart's in the right place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset pauses, enchanted by her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you and he were high school sweethearts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Pretty hokey, huh?  But, what girl wouldn't want the captain of the football team as their lifelong mate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's rare these days... that kind of commitment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy's smile falters a bit.  Somerset notices this.  He from her spell, turns to continue writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... this will only take a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset writes.  Tracy looks over the stack of books: Titles on the spines: BOSCH, A HISTORY OF CHRISTIAN ART, THE ELDER, etc.  Hardcover novels: DANTE'S PURGATORY and CANTERBURY TALES. Tracy stands to look at the novels on top, then sees the paper scraps from Somerset's pocket.  She picks up the pi wallpaper with the pale red rose at its center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset looks up.  Sees her holding the paper rose.  He it, slightly self-conscious, looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy tilts her head, looking at Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a strange way about you, Somerset... I mean in a good way... unusual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset doesn't know what to say.  He pockets the paper

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize.  I'll get out of your hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy stands, takes the chair back to the kitchenette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just... it's nice to hear a man who talks like that.  If David saw that paper, he'd say you're acting like a homosexual.  That's how he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mock indignation) Well!  I guess I won't be showing this to him then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset continues writing.  Tracy sits at the kitchenett table, watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's raining hard.  Mills exits the morgue building with art books and a paper cup of coffee.  He holds one art bo his head as he dashes through deep puddles in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills gets in, puts his coffee on the dash and tosses the books in a box.  He closes the door.  Alone with the soun the rain.  He wipes water off his face, looks at his tire in the rearview mirror. He reaches in the box of books, takes out copies of The Canterbury Tales and Dante's Purgatory.  He makes a face, Dante's Purgatory:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: |                               VII The Lustful         /

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: |                                VI The Gluttonous    /__

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: |                                 V The Avaricious  / |                                   and Prodigal   /_____

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: |                             IV The Slothful  /_________

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: |                     III The Wrathful     /_____________

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: |                      II The Envious    /_______________

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills turns to a bookmark, rests the book on the steering He reads.  He bites his lip, leaning close to the words. concentrates, mouths some of the words to himself.  He fi closes the book, shaking his head, not understanding anyt he's reading.  He starts pounding the book against the st wheel with all his might.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking Dante.  Goddamn, poetry writing freak, mother-fuck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A figure outside the window knocks on the glass.  Mills r down.  A COP in raincoat hands a wet paper bag through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good work, Officer.  Good work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop leaves as Mills quickly rolls the window up and r bag open.  Inside: Cliff Notes for Dante's Purgatory and Canterbury Tales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It still rains outside.  Somerset enters, stops to notice DETECTIVE MILLS painted on the door where his name used t He walks, sees all his belongings have been moved from hi and piled on a small temporary desk in the corner. Somerset sits at the temporary desk, starts organizing th and papers.  Mills enters carrying the box of books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills puts the box on the large desk.  They both settle i attending to their work.  Two men, about five feet apart, trying not to acknowledge the other's presence. Mills takes out his Cliff Notes, looks to see Somerset is occupied, hides them in a desk drawer. Somerset finishes one form, flips it and looks up.  There chalk board nailed to the wall. On the chalkboard:     1 gluttony(x)    5 wrath 2 greed(x)       6 pride 3 sloth          7 lust 4 envy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHONE RINGS.  Both men look at it.  Phone RINGS again

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your name on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills picks up.  Somerset returns to his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Detective Mills here. (lowers voice) Honey, I asked you not to call unless... (listens) What... why?  Okay... okay.  Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills is confused.  He holds the phone out to Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset looks quizzical.  Mills shrugs.  Somerset takes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello? (listens) Yes, well... I appreciate the thought, but... I... (listens) Well, I guess I'd be delighted to. Thank you... goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset gets up, hangs up, puzzled.  Mills is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm invited to have a late supper with you and your wife.  And I accept.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits back down) Tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills looks at the phone, lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A record player on a moving box PLAYS QUIET MUSIC. There's a basketball game with NO VOLUME on the t.v. scre Tracy, Mills and Somerset eat at the kitchen table.  Mill beeper by his beer and occasionally fingers it absently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why aren't you married, Somerset?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy.  What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset adjusts his napkin on his lap, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was close.  It just didn't happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It surprises me you're not married.  It really does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any person who spends a significant amount of time with me finds me... disagreeable.  Just ask your husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills grins, but he means it.  he sips beer.  The convers lapses into long silence.  Somerset concentrates on his p Tracy looks at Mills, who eats while watching the basketb game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Somerset) How long have you lived here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too long.  Much too long. (drinks) What do you think of our fair city?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take the bad with the good, I suppose.  It's... it's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes time to settle in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy looks at Mills.  Somerset can see it is a sore subj

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tracy) You'll get used to it pretty quickly. There are things in any big city that stand out at first.  But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LOW RUMBLING is HEARD as plates begin to rattle and cla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Subway train.  It's right below us/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dishes clatter more.  Coffee cups clink against their saucers.  Tracy holds her cup to stop it, tries to act li is nothing, but she is clearly bothered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll go away in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wait.  The t.v. picture goes fuzzy.  The RUMBLING gr LOUDER, knocks something over in the sink.  Mills continu eating.  Somerset fiddles with his food.  The record play skips, then plays on.  The RUMBLING finally DIES DOWN, ti everything is normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) This real estate guy... a real scum, brought us to see this place a few times.  And, it was nice enough, and the price was right.  I was thinking it was nothing, but I started to notice, he kept hurrying us along.  I mean what could it be?  Why would he only show it like five minutes at a time, before he'd hustle us out the door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills laughs, lamely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We found out the first night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset tries to stay straight, but he can't help laughi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... it's a nice apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls himself together, but only for a moment.  He can it, laughs harder, covering his mouth.  Tracy and Mills l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Oh, fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The record player spins a different album, DIFFERENT MUSI Tracy's clearing the last dishes into the sink.  Mills an Somerset have beers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All television does is teach children that it's really cool to be stupid and eat candy bars all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I've ever met anyone who didn't have a television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy takes a pot of coffee to the table and pours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's weird.  It's un-American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about sports?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy brings over a plate of cookies and puts it on the t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go to movies at least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read.  Remember reading?  What's the last book you read, Mills?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T.V. Guide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills laughs.  Burps.  he turns to Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. (to Somerset) I just have to say, I can't respect any man who's never seen Green Acres.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset gives a blank stare.  Tracy walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never seen The Odd Couple?  The Flintstones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I vaguely recall Wilma, and someone named... Dino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

Scream "fire." Because people don't want to get caught up in anything.  But, a fire... that's entertainment.  They come running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

She sits, dangles her feet through the metal bar opens the book and tries to read by the street light, res her head against the railing.  A WOMAN is HEARD SCREAMING distantly. Tracy looks down the empty street, unsettled.  The woman heard again. Tracy lays back, looks at the sky, holding herself.  We c see the title of the book: PREPARING FOR PARENTHOOD.  The picture of a baby on the cover. Tracy cries, quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...just by studying the underloop... these are not the victim's prints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.  A TECHNICIAN sits before an old computer.  The com green screen shows fingerprints being aligned, compared a rejected; whir - click - whir - click - whir - click.  Mi Somerset watch, bathed in the green glow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't work for me.  I can't believe he wants us to help him stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell knows?  There's plenty of schizoids out there doing dirty deeds they don't want to do.  With tiny voices whispering nasty things in their ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset doesn't buy it.  The technician adjusts a knob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen this baby take three days to finish a cycle, so you guys can go cross your fingers somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset and Mills come from the print lab.  A janitor is mopping the hall.  The computer is HEARD WHIRRING AND CLI onwards.  Somerset sits with a groan on a couch outside t door.  Mills flops beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really meant what you said to Mrs. Gold.  You really believe we'll get him, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I still thought like you.  I'm so far gone from that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, tell me what you think we're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we do is pick up the pieces.  We take all the evidence... all the pictures, statements.  Write everything down and note what time things happened. We take it all, make a nice, neat pile and file it away.  Just in case it's ever needed in a courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're unbelievable.  In my entire life, you're the oldest man I've ever met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen even the most promising clues lead to dead ends.  Hundreds of times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen the same.  I'm not the country hick-boy you seem to think I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset takes out a cigarette and lights it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this city, if all the skeletons came out of all the closets... if every un- revenged corpse were to suddenly rise and walk again, there would be no more room for the living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills slumps back, crosses his arms, closes his eyes to s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't try to tell me you didn't get that rush tonight... that adrenalin.  Like we were getting somewhere. (pause) And, don't try to tell me it was because you thought we found something that would play well in a courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset looks at Mills, puffs the cigarette.  The comput heard: whir - click - whir - click...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our detectives are fast asleep on the couch, leaning agai each other.  People pass and look at them strangely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up, Glimmer Twins.  We have a winner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A windowless classroom.  The captain stands in front with white screen at his side.  The face of a black man, 25, Z projected on the screen from a slide projector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His street name is Zero, as some of you know.  His prints were found at the scene by Detectives Mills and Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIVE hardened POLICE OFFICERS, four men, one woman, sit i chairs facing the captain.  They all wear bullet-proof ve with "POLICE" stencil-painted across them.  Somerset and sit in back, drinking coffee, still trying to wake up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Zero has a long, long history of mental illness.  Serious illness.  He was all over your television sets two years ago after he raped and killed a seventy-three year old woman.  He got off, as the saying goes, on a technicality.  So we watched him on the streets, and he went out of circulation about a year ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he disappeared, what do you want from us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His last place of residence is still in his name.  A search warrant is being pushed through the court as we speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A red-headed cop, CALIFORNIA, 28, raises his meaty hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, have the housing cops walk up and ring the doorbell.  Problem solved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops laugh.  The captain clenches his jaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, California.  When you go in, if Zero isn't home, some of his buddies might be house-sitting.  And besides using, Zero deals, so, you will be very uninvited guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is chatter among the cops.  Somerset leans to Mills the captain continues the briefing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does not seem like our killer, does it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell me.  I'm new in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zero does possess the requisite degree of insanity... but, he doesn't have the desire somehow.  Our killer seems to have more purpose.  More purpose than Zero could ever conceive of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll tag along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset wants no part of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Satisfy our curiosity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills drives, follows a police van.  Somerset rides shotg Mills is pumped, ready.  Somerset takes one Rolaids table fresh roll and chews it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever take one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset pulls out his gun, checks the load.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Never in twenty-four years.  I took my gun out only five times with the actual intention of using it.  I never fired it.  Not once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pulled it once, fired it once.  I never took a bullet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills turns a corner, tires screeching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was my first one of these.  We were a secondary unit, in vice.  I was pretty shaky going in.  When we busted the door, looking for a junkie, the fucking guy opened fire.  One cop was hit in the arm.  He went flying... like in slow motion. (pause) I remember riding in the ambulance.  His arm was like... a piece of meat.  I thought, it's just his arm.  But, he bled to death right there anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.  Somerset opens the window, feels the air on his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did the fire-fight end?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I was doing really good in Philly up till then.  Lots of simple busts. I've always had this weird luck... but, this was wild. (pause) I got that fuck with one shot... right between the eyes.  And the next week, the mayor's pinning a medal on me. Picture in the paper, the whole nine yards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expected it to be bad, because I heard about other guys.  You know... I took a human life.  But, I slept like a baby that night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset eats another antacid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Hemingway wrote somewhere... I can't remember where, but he wrote that, in order to live in a city, you have to have the ability to kill.  I think he meant you truly must be able to do it, not just faking it, to survive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like he knew what he was talking about.

The female cop her gun and the woman obeys, slamming the door. California leads, steps up to apartment 303.  He has a se warrant scotch-taped to the front of his bullet-proof ves

dialogues.text: The black cop brings the ram forward with a splintering t The door flies open.  The cops storm in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up now, motherfucker!  Now!

dialogues.text: The blond cop enters, gun trained, looks around in confus The room's tables, chairs and floor are covered with hund colorful, plastic air fresheners.

Tubes lead from the stained loincloth ar the man's waist and snake under the bed.  The victim is partially covered by what seem to be piles of black spagh
