dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloth... it's sloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black cop touches the black spaghetti.  Holds a piece

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell... those are dead worms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Somerset) Check this out, dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California points with his gun to the end of the black ma right arm.  The hand is gone, severed at the wrist long a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's him.  It's Zero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone call an ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone call a hearse, more like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The female cop has gone to the wall where the sheet is pi up.  She pulls the sheet aside and finds: fifty-two polar pictures; all pictures of Zero tied to the bed, with a da written at the bottom of each.  it is a visual history of physical decay.  The blond cop enters from the other room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, California.  Get your people out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset takes out rubber gloves and puts them on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard him.  Hit the hall, and don't touch anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other cops file out as Mills goes to examine the pola under the sheet.  Somerset replaces the sheet over Zero's California stays by his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like he's some kind of friggin' wax sculpture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset places his finger along Zero's throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset, you... you better look here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills studies the polaroids.  Somerset walks to join him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All pictures of Zero tied to the bed. (crouches) The last one's dated three days ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset looks at the first photo.  In it, Zero is bound gagged, but he is fit, healthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awed) The first photo... it's dated one year ago.  Almost to the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California lifts Zero's blanket to peek under, examining morbid curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mo-ther...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills kneels and lifts the bottom of the sheet off the fl finds an open shoebox.  On the box: TO THE DETECTIVES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California leans close to Zero's gaunt, blindfolded face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got what you deserved, Zero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset leans down beside Mills.  Mills looks through th shoebox.  Inside are plastic, zip-lock bags.  One bag con small clumps of hair, one contains a yellow liquid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A urine sample... hair sample... fingernail clippings.  He's laughing at us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California is still close to Zero's face when suddenly Ze lips twist.  Zero lets out a loud, guttural bark.  Califo jerks back in fear, shouting, falling over a chair. Mills and Somerset reel, standing.  They see California o ground, scared out of his mind, pointing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills and Somerset look towards the bed. Zero's lips move feebly as he lets out a sick, gurgling m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd has gathered.  Mills' car, the police van and two ambulances are parked on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The siege cops are in the hall, holding neighbors at bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three ambulance attendants are at the bed, working on Zer attendant uses wire-cutters to clip Zero's bonds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills and Somerset stand in the middle of one flight of s They are both highly agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way this has gone, I didn't think it was possible, but we may have underestimated this guy.  The type of intestinal fortitude it must take... to keep a man bound for a full year.  To sever his hand and use it to plant fingerprints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want him bad.  I don't just want to catch him anymore.  I want to hurt him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen... we have to divorce ourselves from our emotions here.  We have to keep focusing on the small details.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about you, Somerset, but I feed off my emotions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll string us along all the way if we're not careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills is looking at the floor, burning with anger.  Somer grabs him by the jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you listening to me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills pushes Somerset's hand off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a sudden brilliant flash of light and the SOUND CAMERA ADVANCING.  Mills and Somerset look -- Down the stairs, John is posing as a reporter.  He has hi camera and flash up, pointed at the detectives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes another picture, flashbulb flashing.  Mills char downwards, grabs John by his wrinkled clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John squirms, holds up a laminated PRESS identification p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a right, Officer.  I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills shoves him and John stumbles a few steps, then fall the landing below with a thud.  His glasses fly off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't mean anything.  This is a closed crime scene now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset steps down and pulls Mills back.  John stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do this!  You can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the fuck out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John gets his glasses, scrambles downstairs, out of sight

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The public has a right to know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset yanks Mills harder, till Mills sits on the stair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do those cockroaches get here so quick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pay cops for the inside scoop, and they pay well.  You can hate them, but you better give them something, or they'll make it all up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calming) I'm sorry... I just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's alright.  It's always impressive to see a man feeding off his emotions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills stands with the blase DR. BEARDSLEY, who reviews a chart on a clipboard.  Zero lies inside an oxygen tent wi tubes running into him.  The room is dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year of immobility seems about right, judging by the deterioration of the muscles and spinal cord.  Blood tests show a whole smorgasbord of drugs in his system.  Heroin... crack... even an antibiotic which was administered to keep the bed sores from infecting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills looks into the oxygen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hasn't said anything, or tried to express himself in any way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if his brain were not mush, which it is... he chewed his own tongue off a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills winces, moves away from the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no way he'll survive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective, he'd die right now of shock if you were to shine a flashlight in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tall church on a bustling street.  Smoggy air has eaten stonework.  The homeless are camped out on the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The priest's accommodations are quite spacious and comfor The parish's wealth is evident.  FATHER BLEEKER, 38, stan looking at several 8" by 10" glossies.  He's dressed in h "civilian" clothing, wears his hair short and proper.  Th photos are making him heartsick. Bleeker hands them to Somerset who is seated by a firepla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put them away.  I wish you hadn't brought them into the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I needed for you to see them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Bleeker shakes his head, as if he were trying to f the images.  Somerset replaces the murder photos in a fil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were five principal phases in the development of early Christian art. From Hellenistic through the Renaissance... each period was affected by the decrees of religious leaders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this killer belongs to a certain branch of the church... if he collects religious art from a certain period, I want to know.  I have to narrow it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bleeker walks to an ornate, gold cabinet.  He puts on a p cotton gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The influences on these... things he's done, couldn't have come before the Gothic period.  What's in those pictures is presented far too asymmetrically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bleeker crosses himself before using a key to open the ca He takes out an ancient devotional book and a piece of cl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The colors will tell the tale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bleeker takes the book to a table.  Somerset follows.  Bl lays the cloth under the book, opens the book, tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each sin had a symbolic color.  But the specific color designations changed throughout the ages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset leans to examine Bleeker's illuminated manuscrip Two pages of prayer.  The prose is elaborately formed, surrounded by colorful illustrations of the seven deadly Bleeker's finger points to a rendering of a man seated on rock, guzzling from a jug.  It's been painted in orange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an example.  Gluttony is the sin, and the color is orange.  This particular manuscript is preserved from the 18th century.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the murders, gluttony is green. Greed is yellow.  Sloth is indigo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bleeker steps away and Somerset gets closer to the pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, if this murderer is as precise as you say, then you need to find out at what period in history was gluttony green... and so on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do I look?  If the colors changed so often?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemplates) There is one man... Father Stone. (pause) I haven't heard from him for quite some time.  This was his passion.  He spent his life studying the sins... and preaching against them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chalkboard on the wall:  1 gluttony (x)       5 wrath 2 greed (x)          6 pride 3 sloth (x)          7 lust 4 envy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills is behind his paperwork covered desk, listening to uniformed OFFICER who looks over a report sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zero's landlord said an envelope of cash was in the office mailbox each month. He says, quote, "I never heard a single complaint from this guy and nobody ever complained about him.  He's the best tenant I ever had."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a landlord's dream tenant.  A paralyzed man with no tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who pays his rent on time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring me everything as soon as it's transcribed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officer leaves.  Mills starts sorting through piles o desk.  He doesn't know where to begin. He sits back in his chair, looks at the collage-like coll of pictures pinned on the walls: photos and diagrams of t murder scenes, the drawing of the sun and eye, color page black and white copies of pages from art books. He stares, thinking.  He stands, takes a photocopy off th The killer's first note: Dear Detectives, Long is the way, and hard, that out of hell leads up to the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Milton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big brass lamps hang from the high ceiling.  Mahogany cha tables run down the center floor which is bordered by thr levels of balconies.  People wander like ants in an ant f Mills walks, taking it all in.  He goes to the circulatio Impatient patrons wait in a long line.  He watches the bo HEAD LIBRARIAN, female, 64, help an old man at the desk. She opens the old man's books, runs a laser pen over a ba sticker, pushes a few buttons on a computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near the balcony railing, overlooking the main floor, Mil before a computer card catalog.  He reads the computer sc unsure.  He sets down his pad and pencil, cracks his knuc begins typing on the keyboard.  The computer gives off a BEEP.  Pleased, Mills reads the screen.  Types. On the screen:                 TITLE / PARADISE LOST_ He hits return.  Reads the screen as information on the b appears.  He copies it on his pad, puts the pencil in his He types.  On the screen:      SUBJECT / JACK THE RIPPER_ Hits return.  Again, he copies info from the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A monk opens a formidable gateway door, letting Father Bl and Somerset into a garden courtyard.  Bleeker now wears priestly garb and collar.  The monastery's main building at the end of a pathway.  The building is stately, ivy-co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Stone had a church and congregation of his own.  But, he... there were some problems.  The church is deserted now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Problems?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bleeker continues walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walls of the hallway are carved with images of saints Bleeker whispers to Somerset beside a windowless door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a small orphanage attached to the church, overseen by Father Stone. This was almost thirty years ago. (hesitant) He was an excellent priest, devoted in every way.  Many in his parish demanded his return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bleeker sees a NUN down the hall, coming towards them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allegations were made... Stone was accused of abusing the children in his care.  But, those charges were never substantiated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What abuse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was claimed... that the children were beaten.  And, punished severely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nun is too close for Bleeker to speak freely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is unlocked and opened by the nun.  Somerset ent Bleeker waits outside as the nun closes the door.  It's d FATHER STONE, 73, is in a wheelchair.  Feeble and frail, sunken in their sockets.  He looks up at Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Stone.  I'm a policeman.  I'd like to ask you a few questions, if it's alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whites of Stone's eyes have yellowed.  He seems to no Somerset sits on a stool, close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to ask you about the seven deadly sins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stone reaches out a hand to touch Somerset's face.  Stone extremely long fingernails trail against Somerset's cheek Somerset tries to hide his revulsion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you one of mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saved?  Do you have God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I need to ask about the sins.  Do you understand what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stone takes his hand away, seems to be getting angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a sinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stone's weak arms wheel him away, towards a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are sinners here.  Even here. And, pain waits for them.  Hell is hungry for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stone bites his lip, moaning, disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't realize... they don't know. (pause) Fuck them all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset is shocked by the strength and volume of Stone's voice.  The nun goes to place a comforting hand on Stone' shoulder.  Stone is beginning to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Somerset) They shouldn't have let you disturb him. This shouldn't have been allowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are the children? (much louder) Where are the children?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a mahogany hallway lined with book-carts, we look TH big WINDOW into the head librarian's office.  The elderly librarian is at a computer, chain-smoking, working the ke Mills alternates talking on the telephone and reading thi his pad to the librarian. We cannot hear them, but it's clear Mills is excited as h back and forth, hovering over the librarian, looking at h computer screen, making suggestions, then walking to moni dot-matrix printer which spews a waterfall of computer pa onto the floor.  Back and forth goes Mills, carrying the He closes the pad, puts it in his pocket. The librarian finishes typing, sits back, done.  Mills ha the phone, goes to put it on the librarian's desk, but th drags, knocks a pile of books off a table. The librarian is irritated, goes to pick up the books.  M apologizing.  He goes to watch the printer.  He tears the sheet's perforated edge, gathers the huge pile of printed off the floor. Prize in hand, Mills is so grateful he bends to give the woman a kiss on the cheek, but she pushes him away, now e more annoyed.  Mills goes to leave, knocks over another p books.  Before he can assist, the angry librarian points door.  Mills obeys like a scolded child, exits. The librarian shakes her head in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A once exemplary church, now boarded up, neglected.  Goth style, it stands with deserted brownstones and empty lots rubble as neighbors.  Smokestacks spew smoke distantly. and trucks drive by on a nearby elevated highway, but dow on the street it's a ghost town. There's a building attached to the rear of the church. Somerset's car is parked beside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The windows are covered over.  Somerset and Father Bleeke through.  Somerset has a flashlight with a wide beam.  Th is empty except for broken, cob-web covered school desks few file cabinets.  There are cracked blackboards on the Rats skitter away from the light. Somerset opens a file cabinet drawer.  It's empty.  He wa a door, starts pulling at the rotting boards which seal i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset pushes the door.  He and Bleeker enter from the classroom into the far back corner of the church.  Big ch Shafts of colored light needle through the holes in the p of wood and cloth that cover the broken stained glass win Somerset walks down the center aisle between deteriorated rats run.  Pigeons flap about, dirt drifting off their wi Somerset shines his flashlight forward to the rather barr altar.  To the right, at the top of the altar stairs, the stone statue of a saint with his arms outstretched, welco The life-size saint is covered in spider-webs.  Tiny spid crawl across his eyes, which look down on Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saint Jerome Emiliani.  The patron saint of orphans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset shines the flashlight against the back altar wal revealing a wooden carving of Christ crucified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this still the Lord's house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, even if Father Stone was guilty of everything... if he was hurting children here?  It's still the Lord's house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Bleeker finds this talk insulting and offensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no faith, Somerset?  Have you given up on the church entirely?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (pause) That's not what I've given up on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset notices two ends of a thick rope suspended from ceiling above the center of the altar.  He looks up, foll the rope with the flashlight, when he notices something e His mouth drops.  Bleeker looks, and is equally horrified Above them, in the beam of light: seven large paintings o panels tilted forward at the curve of the ceiling above t altar.  Seven ancient paintings; seven deadly sins. The beam of light moves to the panel to the immediate rig painting of a man kneeling, grasping at gold coins all ar him.  The man is naked, as was the victim of the greed mu The chief color in this panel is a vulgar yellow. The third in the series is sloth.  The painting, in indig shows a man at rest in a pliant bed.  The skeletal man's are rolled up in their sockets.  He is covered in slimy w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The streets are full of patrol cars.  Cops and forensics and exit the church from various doorways.  Saw-horses ar loaded off a flat-bed truck as a police barricade is erec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much activity, as forensics with flashlights go about the business, checking every nook and cranny of the church, l for any sign that someone's been here recently.  Small te floodlights are hoisted on tripods. Two photographers stand at the tops of tall ladders.  Fla photo after flash-photo is taken of the seven paneled tab Near the open church doors, Mills speaks with great anima holding his ream of computer paper.  Somerset looks at th and the tableau, preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our guy's a bookworm, right?  And, I know it's a long shot, but you have to give a picture id and current phone bill to get a library card.  Hey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills snaps his fingers in Somerset's face, gets his atte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made two separate lists of books.  One relating to the sins... Dante's Purgatory, Canterbury Tales... The Dictionary of Catholicism... all the religious stuff.  The second list was books about torture methods, mass murderers... sadomasochism.  Whatever our killer might study to do the things he's done.  Whatever his other interests are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset takes the computer list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.  Everything at the library goes into a computer.  So, you can get in the system and cross-reference...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills fumbles in his pocket, takes out his pad and reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's say you take, Dante's Purgatory, call number eight-five-one-D, and... The Biography of the Marquis de Sade, ninety-two S-A-D-E.  Put those books in the system, and the computer can give you the name of anyone who's ever taken out both those books.  And, it doesn't just give you their name and address, it gives you a complete history of their library reading habits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills slaps the list in Somerset's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (psyched up) If somebody's out there reading Paradise Lost and studying The Life and Times of Charlie Manson, I want to talk to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset looks up from the list, warming to it.  He start looking around, searching for someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset and Mills exit down the stairs.  Somerset's stil searching, holding the list.  He spies a uniformed cop, D

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dario!  Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dario runs up.  Somerset puts his hand on his shoulder an him walk with him.  Mills continues on to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to the Father, this orphanage wasn't around for more than five or six years in the late fifties.  So, I want someone to go to the Department of Child Welfare or City Hall and dig up all the records on this place.  Understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a list of every child who attended this orphanage before it shut down.  Get it on my desk within the hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset releases Dario, who runs to obey.  Somerset goes own car.  Mills is driving to leave, stops, revs the engi Somerset hands the computer list through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought of this all by yourself? This was your brainstorm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Is that so hard for you to believe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pleasant surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not as stupid as I look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills peels away.  Somerset heads to his own car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) I guess not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven large photos hang with the other materials on the w The seven tableau paintings.  Gluttony, greed and sloth, followed by vanity.  Vanity shows a woman standing in fro mirror, staring at her image.  The floor around her is sc with flowers.  The primary color is violet, and as in all paintings, there is a quality of ugliness in the characte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramirez.  Manuel Ramirez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I don't see any Ramirez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lust painting is next.  It shows a man standing over woman.  The woman is nude, under a sheet, and the man's f are bizarre, lecherous.  He wants that woman.  There are on the floor and on the bed.  The color is red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elinski.  Dennis Elinski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Envy is particularly gruesome.  The Devil is seen hoverin the air, wearing a crown, his body orange and slick, wrap a cloak of flames.  His arms held high, his right hand gr sword, a bolt of lightning, arrows, wheat, thistles, etc. left hand, holds a plain globe around which a serpent has wrapped itself.  He looks down at several pitiful mortals pit of fire.  The mortals reach for him, yearn for him, t on their bodies is stretched taut over their bones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atwater?  Paul Atwater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrath shows a man surrounded by vaporous, satanic demons. stands in a puddle of blood, looking at his hands stained and dripping blood.  Other than the rich red, the color i Mills is at his desk, a good portion of the print-out lis draped to the floor.  He rubs his eyes, sighing, gets bac it.  Somerset, at the temporary desk, studies his orphan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, here we go.  Listen to the books this guy's been taking out... (reading list) Basic Homicide Investigation.  Forensic Toxicology... The Encyclopedia of Modern Serial Killers... (looks up, excited) Of Human Bondage.

I tried to be accommodating, but my head began to hurt from his banality.  I almost didn't notice it had happened, but I threw up all over him.  And I couldn't stop myself from laughing." (closes book) No dates indicated.  They're placed on the shelves in no discernible order.  He describes a scab on his arm for five pages, then writes about existential philosophy on the next.

dialogues.text: You're too hard on yourself, Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay to hate this city.  It's natural.  But, there is a bright side in all this.  There is.  You want to hear it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy is able to muster a small smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, yes.  Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the trace on his bank account?  The guns?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orphanage is all we have.  His bank account is only five years old and it started as cash.  There's no credit history, no employment history.  We even tried to trace his furniture.  All we know for sure is he's wealthy, well educated and totally insane.  We may never know how he got that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset stands looking in at Doe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he is John Doe, by choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do we get to question him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't.  This goes to court now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This doesn't make sense, captain.  He wouldn't just turn himself in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there he sits.  It's not supposed to make sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not finished!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wound way too tight on this, Mills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset... help me out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset looks at them.  Says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The captain leaves.  Mills is furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it, Somerset.  You know Johnny's fucking with us.  He's pissing in our faces again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow up.  You and I are, probably for the first time ever, in total agreement. He wouldn't just stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... what the fuck, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Doe's only two murders away from finishing his masterpiece, right?  But, can you even conceive of what might happen next?  I mean, can you tell me how he's going to go about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell you this; I recognize his lawyer.  His name is Mark Swarr.  He's the one who kept Zero out of prison. (pause) We'll wait for John Doe's plea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills is at the desk with his feet up, stares at the chal 1 gluttony (x)       5 lust (x) 2 greed (x)          6 wrath 3 sloth (x)          7 envy 4 pride (x)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clock on the wall says 4:45.  Somerset packs books into b preparing for his eventual departure.  The captain opens door and steps into the office.  He clears his throat, lo like there is something very wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills and Somerset stand together.  The captain is behind desk with the D.A., Martin Talbot, seated in front of him Swarr addresses them all, seems nervous, but in control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My client says there are two more bodies... two more dead, hidden away. He will take Detective Mills to these bodies, but only Detective Mills.  Only at six o'clock, today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swarr wipes his brow with a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he admires you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to captain) This is all part of his game plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Doe claims that if the detective does not accept this offer, the bodies will never be found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, counselor, I'm inclined to let them rot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills walks up into Swarr's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like what you do for a living?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back off, Mills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm required by law to serve my clients to the best of my ability, and to serve their interests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills eases off.  Talbot is agitated, tapping a finger on gold tooth in his mouth.  He looks at Swarr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't make deals like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to have to pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My client... he also wishes that I inform you, if you do not accept, he will plead insanity, across the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him try.  I'd like to see him try!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come now, Martin.  Even he knows, with the nature of these crimes, I could get him off with such a plea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talbot stands, wringing his hands.  Mills and Somerset ar looking at each other, thinking it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not letting this conviction slide. I can tell you that, right here and right now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says, if you accept, under his specific conditions, he will sign a full confession and plead guilty... right here, and right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talbot looks at Swarr with hatred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on... just a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset turns to Talbot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he were to plead insanity... this conversation is admissible.  The fact that he's blackmailing us with his plea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, my client reminds you, two more people are dead.  The press would have a field day if they found out the police didn't seem too concerned about finding them... giving them proper burial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do it.  I want to finish it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset is thinking it through.  He looks at Mills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to captain) Well... let's get the fucking lawyer out of the room, and we can talk about how this whole thing's going to go down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's here.  With me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset can see through the heat warp.  Doe stands facin from the altar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I want?  The same you... I want an ending.  Stay where you are.  Put your gun on the floor and slide it all the way down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset obeys, bends, slides the gun down the aisle till hits the bottom altar stair.  He keeps walking, slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see him.  Show me Mills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the altar, Doe is sweating hard, standing over Mills. is slumped forward on the floor, unconscious.  His bullet vest has been removed. Mills' hands are tied tight together in front of him, tie one end of the thick rope suspended from the ceiling.  Do the other end of the rope, has his gun tucked under his b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an intelligent man, Somerset. You understand what you're a part of, don't you?  When this is finished, it will seem surreal, but it will be a whole, crystalline reality.  And, no one will be able to deny it, no matter how hard they try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe's voice is thick with passion.  Somerset is about hal down the aisle, still moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a murderer.  That's all.  The only way you've distinguished yourself is by your particular brutality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe walks across the altar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that's not true.  You know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're killing innocent people, and I should admire you?  You're doing it because it gives you pleasure.  That's the only purpose... your sick pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe picks up a container of gasoline, looks out at Somers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay where you are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't deny my personal desires.  I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe begins dousing Mills with gasoline, covering Mills' b clothing.  Mills stirs, coming to.  He coughs, choking on gas and fumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, I don't mourn the victims in this any more than I mourn the thousands who died in Sodom and Gomorrah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset looks fearful.  He starts approaching again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you've done is cause more misery and pain!  You've given people all the more reason to believe there is no God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset eyes his gun at the bottom of the stairs. Doe sees Somerset moving, throws the gas can away, takes gun.  Doe walks to the edge of the altar, all the time ho his end of the rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset is twitching with anger, looking at the gun abou fifteen feet in front of him. Mills manages to look up, weak, his eyes barely able to o because of the stinging gasoline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe takes one step down off the altar.  Somerset is still forward, hands out away from his body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really think I'm just going to let this happen?!  You think I'm going to let him die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe fires his gun and the bullet slams into the front of Somerset's bullet-proof vest.  Somerset flies back, knock over a rack of candles on his way to the floor. Doe walks quickly back onto the altar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motherfucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills tries to grab at Doe as he passes, but Doe turns an Mills in the ribs.  Mills cringes in pain. Somerset lays in the aisle, on his stomach, gasping.  He catch his breath, his twisted face pressed against the fl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you speak of God, Somerset? When was the last time you spoke His name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills tries to rub the gas out of his eyes with his bound His mind works feverishly.  He looks around to see where then he searches the floor.  We can see, inside his open the bleeding, upside-down cross Doe has cut into his ches Doe walks back to shout angrily down at Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you last speak His name?  Was it in prayer?  Or, did you say the Lord's name after you stubbed your big toe?  Or, did you use His name to curse another man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset holds his chest, blinking, trying not to black o Mills finds a piece of broken stained glass on the floor. picks it up, palms it, still choking on gasoline. Doe walks over to the statue of Saint Jerome Emiliani, pu the rope from above so it goes taut and Mills' arms raise his head.  Doe wraps the rope around Emiliani's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to kill you, Johnny.  I'm going to see you dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe begins twisting the loose end of the rope around the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The irony, David, is that you policemen and I want the same things.  But, you are so short sighted.  In this city, where you can see a deadly sin on every street corner... and in every home, we want repentance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills clutches the glass piece and starts cutting the rop above his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want good over evil.  We want values instilled in the children.  We want a world where a man or woman can lead a decent life. (pause) Wisdom, understanding, counsel, fortitude, knowledge, piety, and fear of the Lord.  Such simple concepts.  Why are they non-existent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset manages to life his head, struggles to his knees

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) Let him go, God damn you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe checks to make sure the rope around Saint Emiliani is tightening the knots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were two men once, who had wonderful gardens.  Two gardens of flowers that went on as far as the eye could see.  Beautiful gardens... the fragrance was inspiration in itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe stands behind Emiliani, heaves against the statue. Mills watches, gritting his teeth, rubbing the glass agai rope, fingers bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, both gardens were beset by problems.  Weeds started to take root, and there were infestations of insects and diseases.  The gardens started to turn putrid.  And, one man fought to save his garden, because he could never forget how it once was.  Everyday he cut the weeds, and killed the insects. Fought the diseases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe finally topples the statue, down the altar stairs, an other end of the rope pulls Mills upwards, screaming in p Mills is held, about eight feet in the air, legs dangling

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man never had a beautiful garden again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other man plowed his garden under. (pause) He plowed it under the soil.  He started over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset gets to his feet, steadying himself on a pew. Doe walks across the altar, picks up a long metal pole wi thick wick and candle snuffer on the end.  He lights the from a near candle.  The flame burns long and thin.  He l down at Somerset, takes out his gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay there, Somerset.  Or, I'll kill him right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe holds the flaming pole up, near Mills. Somerset stops.  He looks up at Mills. Mills is straining.  He nods to Somerset, and Somerset se Mills cutting at the rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright... you don't have to do this, John.  You've already made your point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I chose this?  Can you even begin to understand how painful my existence has been?  It's like... like having every sense heightened beyond comprehension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe lowers the flame, standing below and beside Mills, wi attention focused on Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that the stench of the street coats your throat like bile.  So, sugar is so sweet it... it makes your bones ache to the marrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're insane.  That's why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seething) No!  You're wrong!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills continues cutting, bleeding, almost through the rop begins to swing his feet slightly, his body swaying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was chosen.  And I've wished a thousand times I could have been a normal man.  Like David Mills, a common man... with a common life.  But, wishing that is my sin.  I can't have it and I shouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe steps towards Mills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant what I said.  I admire David Mills.  I envy David Mills. (pause) Envy is my sin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as Doe is to put the flame to Mills, the rope is fin cut through.  Mills drops, swinging his legs forward, sma Doe in the face, knocking Doe's glasses off. Mills hits the floor with a thud. Somerset runs forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe has fallen back, dropping the metal pole.  Mills scra to his feet and charges at Doe, shouting. Doe squints, screaming, raises his gun.  Fires twice! The bullets catch Mills in mid-run, and carry him off his backwards. Somerset grips his own gun, just as Mills' body falls, tu off the altar area and down the stairs in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset lets out a scream of pain and rage that chokes i throat.  He falls to his knees and halts Mills' body. Somerset's shaking, unable to breathe, turning Mills over cradling his head in his arms.  Tears come to his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David... David?  Please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the altar, Doe throws his gun away.  he starts feeling him, unsteady, looking for his glasses. Mills' eyes are closed.  He is still, bloody.  He swallow With one gasp, without a word, he is dead. Somerset looks up at Doe, vision blurred by rage and tear Doe stands, putting on his glasses, faces Somerset. Somerset lays Mills' body down.  Stands, walks up towards altar, raises his gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doe stands, quaking, teeth clenched, fists balled up.  He for the bullets, falls to his knees. The gun trembles in Somerset's hand as Somerset brings th barrel to Doe's face.  A millisecond's pause.  Somerset c the angle of fire.  BLAM, he blows John Doe's arm to piec splattering explosion. Doe screams, falling back, on the altar floor.

dialogues.speaker: VIEWED FROM FAR BACK IN THE CHURCH
dialogues.text: The entire church with its candles frames the torture: Somerset walks to where Doe flops horribly, bleeding.  So aims, shoots Doe in the leg.  Doe screams, rolling, tryin crawl away, knocking over candle racks.  Somerset follows shoots Doe's other leg.  He shoots Doe in the other arm. begin to rise and spread quickly amongst the pews.  Doe continues to spasm, wrenching, hand slapping the bloody f BLAM, BLAM, BLAM.  Somerset steps back from Doe, overturn rack of candles on top of him.  He steps away.  Watching. Flames begin rising on Doe's clothing.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN DOE'S FACE
dialogues.text: Doe's face, covered in blood, twisted in agony, helpless, rising.  He continues screaming. His glasses crack from the heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke billows from the windows.  The fire is moving quick ravenous.  It's just starting to light up the night. From the front door, Somerset walks weeping, carrying Mil body in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The seven deadly sin tableau burns. Flames cause the paint to bubble and blacken.  Gluttony, and sloth are already halfway gone. Flames eat at pride, lust. Wrath and envy are being consumed.  Wrath goes last.  A m bloodied hands, in tones of blue.  Flames devour it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A field of blue.  Cops in orderly rows.  The funeral of D Mills.  Many police officials and politicians stand in tr Somerset is here, in his dress blue uniform.  He stares f still numb, beaten.  Rifles are raised by a corps of rifl Blanks explode from the barrels.  They reload in unison. Somerset looks towards the grace where Mills' casket lies an American flag.  Tracy is there. Tracy stands surrounded by strangers at the grave-site. head is lowered.  She cries.  Each blast of the rifle sal causes her to react with a start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The funeral is over.  Somerset stands at the edge of the graveyard, looking at the distant city.  Behind him, the mourners are still filing out to their cars. The captain approaches.  He comes to stand beside Somerse similarly solemn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I should do this. (pause) We found the motel room Doe must have been staying in after you found his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset hasn't acknowledged the captain, still looking a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway... we found this in his belongings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The captain takes out a sealed envelope.  Somerset takes On the envelope: DETECTIVE SOMERSET, handwritten, in red

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy and Somerset stand near a moving truck in front of apartment building.  MOVERS carry Tracy's belongings to t truck.  Mills' car is attached to be towed behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could say something... (pause) Something to... I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll keep in touch.  I'll come visit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll write to you when we get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of yourself. (pause) Take care of the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy nods.  There's nothing left for them to say.  They' empty.  It's time for them to give a gesture, a kiss, or to say goodbye, but neither makes the first move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all, Mrs. Mills.  We got everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Movers latch up the back of the truck while the driver cl in and fires up the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Somerset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset walks away.  Tracy walks away, gets in the passe side of the moving truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidewalks jammed with people, hurrying.  Somerset walks i fog, hands in his pockets.  He stops at a corner, but doe cross.  He stands there, looks up. At the city around him.  The buildings towering over him. At the cars, buses and taxies racing in the streets, blow their horns and spouting soot. Somerset reaches into his jacket pocket, takes out the en from John Doe.  He studies it in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Oh... man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens it.  He takes out a small note, handwritten.  It

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somerset looks up again, mortified, fighting to keep cont his emotions.  He looks around: At the miserable people, walking past him. At a man at the top of the subway station stairs, sitting cardboard box, holding out a cup, rattling the change ins A father passes by, holding his young son's hand.  Somers turns to watch them as they pass.  The gather reaches to the boy up and carry him.  The boy holds tight. For some reason, this makes Somerset ache with sorrow. The father hugs his son to him, kisses him on the cheek. boy returns the kiss, with great affection. Somerset watches them disappear in the mass of humanity. looks back at the note in his hand. He tears the note up, into little pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck moves along in steady traffic.  Tracy sits besi driver.  She looks out at the city across the river. She reaches into her pocket, takes out a small manila env She opens the envelope and slides two keys on a keychain into her palm. She's looking at the keys when she notices something abou envelope.  She reopens it, takes out a small folded piece paper.  She unfolds it: It is the piece of wallpaper with the pale rose at its ce She smiles very faintly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cars roll by in the street.  Cops come and go. Somerset walks up the stairs into the precinct house.
